description: From Middle English creken, criken, metathesis of Old English cearcian (“to chatter, creak, crash, gnash”), from Proto-West Germanic *krakōn (“to crash, crack, creak”), from Proto-Germanic *krakōną, from Proto-Indo-European *gerh₂- (“to make a sound, cry hoarsely”), ultimately of imitative origin.
Compare also Old English crǣccettan, crācettan (“to croak”), Albanian grykë (“throat”). More at crack.

entries.meaning: The sound produced by anything that creaks; a creaking.

verbs.description: creak (third-person singular simple present creaks, present participle creaking, simple past and past participle creaked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a prolonged sharp grating or squeaking sound, as by the friction of hard substances.
examples: Then when the four ropes were arranged the coffin was placed upon them. He watched it descend; it seemed descending for ever. At last a thud was heard; the ropes creaked as they were drawn up.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To produce a creaking sound with.
examples: I miss the polished brass, the powerful black horses,
The drivers creaking the seats of the baroque hearses

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To suffer from strain or old age.
examples: Fascinating though this high-minded re-reading was, certain crucial joints of the play creaked a good deal under the strain.
